title: Authors and Citation
text: Soonhong Cho. Author. Doeun Kim. Author. Chad Hazlett. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Cho S, Kim D, Hazlett C (2024). gpss: Gaussian Processes Social Science. R package version 0.1, http://doeunkim.org/gpss/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {gpss: Gaussian Processes in Social Science},   author = {Soonhong Cho and Doeun Kim and Chad Hazlett},   year = {2024},   note = {R package version 0.1},   url = {http://doeunkim.org/gpss/}, }

title: Gaussian Processes in Social Science
text: Gaussian Process (GP) combines highly flexible non-linear regression approach rigorous handling uncertainty. key feature approach , can used produce conditional expectation function representing mode posterior conditional distribution, ``choose particular model fit’’ construct uncertainty estimates conditional putting full faith model. valuable uncertainty estimates reflect lesser knowledge locations near, , beyond edge observed data, results approaches become highly model-dependent. first offer accessible explanation GPs, provide implementation suitable social science inference problems, reduces number user-chosen hyperparameters three zero. illustrate settings GPs can valuable: conventional approaches poor properties due model-dependency/extrapolation data-sparse regions. Specifically, demonstrate usefulness GPs contexts () treated control models needed groups poor covariate overlap; (ii) regression discontinuity, depends model estimates taken just beyond edge supporting data; (iii) interrupted time-series designs, models fitted prior event extrapolated .

title: Gaussian Processes in Social Science
text: can install latest version running:

title: Gaussian Processes in Social Science
text: version uses Rcpp extensively speed reasons. means need right compilers machine.

title: Gaussian Processes in Social Science
text: Windows, need install RTools haven’t already. still difficulty installing says compilation failed, try installing without support multiple architectures:

title: Gaussian Processes in Social Science
text: order compile C++ package, RcppArmadillo require compilers installed machine. may already , can install running: problems install Mac OSX, specifically getting errors either lgfortran lquadmath, try open Terminal try following: Also see section 2.16
code: xcode-select --install curl -O http://r.research.att.com/libs/gfortran-4.8.2-darwin13.tar.bz2 sudo tar fvxz gfortran-4.8.2-darwin13.tar.bz2 -C /

title: Gaussian Processes in Social Science
code: library(gpss) data(lalonde) cat_vars=c("race_ethnicity", "married") all_vars= c("age","educ","re74","re75","married", "race_ethnicity")  X = lalonde[,all_vars]   Y = lalonde$re78 D = lalonde$nsw  X_train = X[D==0,] Y_train = Y[D==0]  X_test <- X[D == 1,] Y_test <- Y[D == 1]  gp_train.out <- gp_train(X = X_train, Y = Y_train, optimize=TRUE,                          mixed_data = TRUE,                           cat_columns = cat_vars)  gp_predict.out <- gp_predict(gp_train.out, X_test)

title: gp_optimize — gp_optimize
text: optimizes S2 using MLE. function automatically runs gp_train(..., optimize=TRUE).

title: gp_optimize — gp_optimize
text: K kernel matrix (covariates) Y Y vector (outcome variable)

title: gp_optimize — gp_optimize
text: s2opt optimized s2 value nlml likelihood value optimal point

title: gp_predict — gp_predict
text: predict outcome values testing points feeding results obtained gp_train()

title: gp_predict — gp_predict
text: gp list-form object obtained gp_train() Xtest data frame matrix testing data set

title: gp_predict — gp_predict
text: Xtest_scaled testing data scaled form Xtest original testing data set Ys_mean_scaled predicted values Y scaled form Ys_mean_orig predicted values Y original scale Ys_cov_scaled covariance predicted Y scaled form Ys_cov_orig covariance predicted Y original scale f_cov_orig covariance target function original scale b bandwidth value obtained gp_train() s2 s2 value obtained gp_train()

title: gp_predict — gp_predict
code: data(lalonde) cat_vars=c("race_ethnicity", "married") all_vars= c("age","educ","re74","re75","married", "race_ethnicity")  X = lalonde[,all_vars] Y = lalonde$re78 D = lalonde$nsw  X_train = X[D==0,] Y_train = Y[D==0] X_test <- X[D == 1,] Y_test <- Y[D == 1]  gp_train.out <- gp_train(X = X_train, Y = Y_train, optimize=TRUE, mixed_data = TRUE, cat_columns = cat_vars) gp_predict.out <- gp_predict(gp_train.out, X_test)

title: gp_rdd — gp_rdd
text: perform RD using GP functions

title: gp_rdd — gp_rdd
code: gp_rdd(   X,   Y,   cut,   alpha = 0.05,   b = NULL,   trim = FALSE,   trim_k_value = 0.1,   scale = TRUE )

title: gp_rdd — gp_rdd
text: X forcing variable Y Y vector (outcome variable) cut cut point alpha confidence level (default = 0.05) b bandwidth (default = NULL) trim logical value indicating whether want automatic trim specific value trim_k_value (default=FALSE) trim_k_value numerical value indicating kernel value want trim (default = 0.1) scale logical value indicating whether want scale covariates (default = TRUE)

title: gp_rdd — gp_rdd
text: tau estimated treatment effect se standard error tau

title: gp_rdd — gp_rdd
code: n <- 100 tau <- 3 cut <- 0 x <- rnorm(n, 0, 1) y <- rnorm(n, 0, 1) + tau*ifelse(x>cut, 1, 0) gp_rdd.out <- gp_rdd(x, y, cut) gp_rdd_plot(gp_rdd.out)

title: gp_rdd_plot — gp_rdd_plot
text: draw RD plot using results obtained gp_rdd()

title: gp_rdd_plot — gp_rdd_plot
text: gp_rdd_res list-form results obtained gp_rdd() l_col character value indicating color left side cutoff point (default = "blue") r_col character value indicating color right side cutoff point (default = "red")

title: gp_rdd_plot — gp_rdd_plot
text: gg RD ggplot

title: gp_rdd_plot — gp_rdd_plot
code: library(ggplot2) n <- 100 tau <- 3 cut <- 0 x <- rnorm(n, 0, 1) y <- rnorm(n, 0, 1) + tau*ifelse(x>cut, 1, 0) gp_rdd.out <- gp_rdd(x, y, cut) gp_rdd_plot(gp_rdd.out) +  geom_vline(xintercept = cut, lty="dashed")

title: gp_train — gp_train
text: train GP model training data set

title: gp_train — gp_train
code: gp_train(   X,   Y,   b = NULL,   s2 = 0.3,   optimize = FALSE,   scale = TRUE,   mixed_data = FALSE,   cat_columns = NULL,   Xtest = NULL )

title: gp_train — gp_train
text: X set covariate data frame matrix Y Y vector (outcome variable) b bandwidth (default = NULL) s2 noise fraction Y explained X (default = 0.3) optimize logical value indicate whether automatic optimized value S2 used. FALSE, users must define s2. (default = FALSE) scale logical value indicate whether covariates scaled. (dafault = TRUE) mixed_data logical value indicate whether covariates contain categorical/binary variable (default = FALSE) cat_columns character numerical vector indicating categorical variables (default = NULL) Xtest data frame matrix testing covariates. necessary non-overlapping categorical value exists training testing data sets. (default = NULL)

title: gp_train — gp_train
text: post_mean_scaled posterior distribution Y scaled form post_mean_orig posterior distribution Y original scale post_cov_scaled posterior covariance matrix scaled form post_cov_orig posterior covariance matrix original scale K kernel matrix X prior_mean_scaled prior distribution mean scaled form X.orig original matrix data set X X.init original matrix data set X categorical variables expanded form X.init.mean initial mean values X X.init.sd initial standard deviation values X Y.init.mean initial mean value Y Y.init.sd initial standard deviation value Y K kernel matrix X Y scaled Y X scaled X b bandwidth s2 sigma squared alpha alpha value Rasmussen Williams (2006) p.19) L L value Rasmussen Williams (2006) p.19) mixed_data logical value indicating whether X contains categorical/binary variable cat_columns character numerical vector indicating location categorical/binary variables X cat_num numerical vector indicating location categorical/binary variables expanded version X Xcolnames column names X

title: gp_train — gp_train
code: data(lalonde) cat_vars=c("race_ethnicity", "married") all_vars= c("age","educ","re74","re75","married", "race_ethnicity")  X = lalonde[,all_vars] Y = lalonde$re78 D = lalonde$nsw  X_train = X[D==0,] Y_train = Y[D==0] X_test <- X[D == 1,] Y_test <- Y[D == 1]  gp_train.out <- gp_train(X = X_train, Y = Y_train, optimize=TRUE, mixed_data = TRUE, cat_columns = cat_vars) gp_predict.out <- gp_predict(gp_train.out, X_test)

what: gpss: Gaussian Processes in Social Science — gpss
title: gpss: Gaussian Processes in Social Science — gpss
text: Gaussian Process (GP) combines highly flexible non-linear regression approach rigorous handling uncertainty. key feature approach , can used produce conditional expectation function representing mode posterior conditional distribution, ``choose particular model fit'' construct uncertainty estimates conditional putting full faith model. valuable uncertainty estimates reflect lesser knowledge locations near, , beyond edge observed data, results approaches become highly model-dependent. first offer accessible explanation GPs, provide implementation suitable social science inference problems, reduces number user-chosen hyperparameters three zero. illustrate settings GPs can valuable: conventional approaches poor properties due model-dependency/extrapolation data-sparse regions. Specifically, demonstrate usefulness GPs contexts () treated control models needed groups poor covariate overlap; (ii) regression discontinuity, depends model estimates taken just beyond edge supporting data; (iii) interrupted time-series designs, models fitted prior event extrapolated .
